segments.text: Interview with Dr. Laura Summers, visiting fellow at Sri Lanka University, Bangkok, Thailand.
Question one.
Do you feel that the Khmer Rouge should be involved in a coalition government?
Why?
Let me begin to answer this question by saying something about how I understand the position of those who oppose having the Khmer Rouge in a coalition government.
I think most of the...
campaign against Khmer Rouge involvement in the coalition.
is motivated by or informed by some Western notions of justice or morality.
I have friends, and I'm sure you have friends, who say things like, they're responsible for so much killing, they don't deserve to be in power, or it would be immoral
for them to be put back in power because it was for example unthinkable or immoral that the fascists in Germany should be put back into power after they were defeated in the war

well i want to stress that the arguments that you hear about this tend to issue out of western experience and western values and they represent a projection of certain democratic ideas of representation
And while I don't reject those values, and of course we support those values, I want to suggest to you that these arguments are unrealistic.
They're unrealistic if you look at the problem of a coalition government within the framework of Cambodian politics.

so now let me answer the question that's the introduction but my answer to the question is that of course the Khmer Rouge must be involved in the coalition government and I say this for two reasons I say of course they must be involved because of certain political and that includes military realities on the ground
And the second reason I say they must be involved is, and I want to be very careful about how I say this, they must be involved because in some sense I would argue they deserve to be involved.
And I say they deserve to be involved from the standpoint of what has been happening inside Cambodian nationalism.
and when you look at Khmer Rouge from that standpoint you can see that they still have some support not as much as they had in the early 70s and maybe more than they deserve in quotation marks

But the simple historical fact of the matter is that they are recognized by some Cambodians as the leading nationalist force, as a group of people who still by and large represent the interests of poor country people, poor peasants, and as people who

in standing up against the Vietnamese invasion have in some sense vindicated themselves although I think nobody has forgotten about the suffering and the killings from the 1970s that would be pretty impossible because the scale was large OK, but let me sum up by saying
They really must be involved in the coalition because that's the price, in some sense, for peace.
Le Premier Rouge still have the largest, most disciplined, most coherent
army and political movement whatever we think of it and certainly it's not a movement or party that many foreigners would join whatever we think of it they have political power on the ground
And as you know in political science, we're talking about conflict resolution, we're talking about settlement of disputes.
This is a process which involves compromise amongst those groups which have power of one sort or another.

either military power as in the case of Khmer Rouge royal and culturalist power in the case of Sihanouk whose army isn't so impressive but Sihanouk himself is widely recognized as being essential to a coalition because monarchy is central to the sense of stability and well-being in Cambodian society so Sihanouk has a form of power
which we can label social and cultural power, as well as political power.
Monarchy is the fulcrum and has always been the center of Khmer politics.
It's probably less the center of Khmer politics now than it was 20 or 30 years ago.
But again, it's still important.
Sihanouk represents a kind of power which must be taken into account in a settlement.
And similarly, the KPNLF must be involved in the settlement.
The KPNLF involves a lot of middle class, urban people, people with technical skills, former high civil servants, former teachers, the best and the brightest, if you like, of Cambodians.

they don't have much support in the countryside peasants don't understand that party and that movement very much but nevertheless if you're going to have a government that can really govern a government that can pursue development policies you've got to have engineers you've got to have accountants you've got to have statisticians you've got to have bankers financiers and businessmen and those are the KPM people they must be included in a coalition as well also and this is not unimportant they're the people who speak
the best to foreigners.
They're the people who have been educated abroad.
They're the people who can provide an important bridge between Cambodian politics and the politics of the rest of the world.
And let me just finish by saying that the Hun Sen Heng Sum Rin Party must, of course, be included in the coalition, too.
All four parties have to be included in the coalition.
and I say this because they have succeeded with a lot of Vietnamese and Soviet help in putting together a new state administration not a very strong one

but in some sense a reasonably effective one in administrative terms I don't think that the Hang Sam Rin Hun Sen party is very strong politically and that's because if you ask the question who has power and what kind of power they have the answer to those questions in the case of the Hang Sam Rin Hun Sen people is

they have vietnamese military power behind them they're the base of that administration the base of that communist party is the vietnamese army right they've had 10 years to try to build it into something more and something different

and there really isn't a great deal of evidence to suggest that they've made much progress Nevertheless, the administration functions a bit the hospitals are functioning, the schools are functioning you've got a lot of people drawing salaries from the ministries and there's a framework there

and there's a party with very low morale to which most of these civil servants have rallied they join it because it's associated with getting jobs there's a framework there of a sort of administrative power or state power which has to be taken into account in a settlement and in the formation of let me stress an interim coalition government

when people talk about coalition government now they're talking about two different kinds of coalitions firstly they're talking about some form of armistice or ceasefire that can be arranged in the near future alongside the creation of an interim political authority

the term authority was used by the Paris conference because the term government has become so controversial so the CGDK wants to defend its legal position as the only worldwide recognized legal government and the Hun Sen people still want to claim that their government ought to be recognized so the politics of this is being worked on internationally by

more and more people speaking in terms of the formation of an interim coalition authority which would oversee an armistice along with some sort of international control mechanism and which would be the Cambodian component of some sort of international control mechanism which would arrange elections

in which all parties could participate and which would presumably produce an elected coalition government which would be a proper legally constituted government formed as a result of an act of self-determination on the part of all Cambodian voters

maybe that's enough on that question question two have the Vietnamese pulled out of Cambodia sub question a why won't they let the UN verify their withdrawal and question sub question b will they come back if the guerrilla forces get too close to Phnom Penh

Well, these are straightforward questions, I'll take them in order Yes, the Vietnamese have pulled out of Khenpo Chia in one particular sense The Vietnamese have pulled out their organized combat battalions

they have turned full responsibility for battlefield fighting over to the Heng San Ren army to put this in another way so in that sense in that specific military sense the Vietnamese army has pulled out Kampuchea but politically speaking Vietnam has not pulled out
of Campuchia, not at all.
Not at all, and there should be no confusion about this.
The Vietnamese have admitted they have left an advisory corps behind.
There have been reliable reports that there are five Vietnamese consulates, so-called, strategically placed around the country to oversee, to supervise the fighting.
So there's a large advisory, military advisory structure there.

and there is undoubtedly still a core of Vietnamese advisors attached to the Heng Sam Rin Communist Party political bureau and central committee to continue to advise them about political matters about propaganda about what to say this week or tomorrow or what have you there's no doubt about it and politically too Vietnam has not pulled out of Kampuchea in the following sense

From the beginning, the invasion, the replacement of the Pol Pot government by a government of Vietnam's own choosing, was part of a broad political and social and economic and historical strategy or development on the part of the Vietnamese Communist Party and the Vietnamese revolution.
the developmental outlook goes something like this.
Khenpochiya allows to form, in some sense, an essential part of
Indochina, if I can use the old colonial term, in economic terms, because the French began the process of economic modernization in that part of Southeast Asia.
by coordinating the economies of those former French territories.
Saigon, as it was known then, was the economic capital of Indochina.
Hanoi was the political capital.
The Governor General of France was based in Hanoi, and he oversaw political, economic, and social developments in all five territories of Indochina from Hanoi.

So from those times Laos and Cambodia were two provinces if you like of Indochina which was centered in Vietnam Now for some of the old generation of Vietnamese Communist Party this formative colonial experience which was 90 years long effectively in the case of Cambodia

in economic materialist terms remember they're serious Marxists in economic materialist terms this determined historically that the development economically and historically of all the territories here would be integrated for all times

and in in modern market terms it makes some sense this argument Vietnam's a very densely populated too heavily populated country there's not enough land to feed all of the Vietnamese Vietnam technologically speaking is fairly advanced highly urbanized lots of factories very well educated population but the country lacks raw materials for those factories

Laos is rich in minerals and timber and lots of raw materials which are necessary in Vietnam to keep the industries going Campuchia is rich in land, rich in food and during the French colonial period Campuchian food was used to feed the people in Goch in China at the same time that the French invested in industries and rubber plantations there so there's a long
momentum if you like behind Vietnamese nationalism and Vietnamese communism which leads a lot of the leadership in the party to see Laos and Campuchia as absolutely vital to their national security

and their national security in economic terms as well as in military terms the Vietnamese will often say things like we have been invaded from the sea so many times in the last 10 centuries and we have been invaded from the West by the Thais incidentally on occasion through Cambodia through Laos

you know so many times and they can recite all the wars and the names of the military commanders and the kings who were involved and so it it is a part of Vietnamese nationalism and Vietnamese communism that these security considerations of these economic considerations make them at the very least extremely conscious of the importance of having

sympathetic governments in Laos and Cambodia at a minimum the governments have to be sympathetic and for some Vietnamese communists and nationalists it goes further than that there is an expectation that those governments must be allies of Vietnam that they must cooperate fully with the Vietnamese in economic development and in military security matters that in fact
the whole of former French Indochina must be regarded historically and in practical policy terms as one solidarity block the Vietnamese to use this language which is

inspired by Brezhnev's old limited sovereignty doctrine which was developed in Eastern Europe and the Vietnamese look at Eastern Europe and the relationship between the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe and they draw parallels between themselves and Laos and Cambridgeshire and so they formulate these theoretical arguments and this language of an Indo-Chinese solidarity bloc which they used up until about 85 and then they dropped it
on the basis of their Marxist theorizing and their historical analysis.
But more to the point of your question,

they formulate real policies on the basis of this theory and on the basis of these historical conditions and so in the very broadest sense this is why they invaded Cambodia this is why they toppled the Pol Pot government and put their own government in power and set up a new communist party set up a new communist army which would be loyal

to their own and allied with their own and set up a new state a state of an entirely new character there's never been a socialist state in Cambodia before like this one Paul Park of course had hardly any central government at all so this is the first time you have the kind of full apparatus
state apparatus in Cambodia.

I guess maybe to go back to the first question, it's this apparatus which has somehow to be taken into account now when people talk about an interim political authority or a post-election coalition government.

well I think I've answered your second question already second sub-question will they come back if the guerrilla forces get too close to Phnom Penh of course they will of course they will there's no doubt about it because one politically I'm saying they never left you know it's a trick if you like they pull out the troops so you know journalists can go take pictures and say ah they're gone you know Pilger can put in his film

shots of the Vietnamese withdrawing but that conveys the wrong sort of political message militarily yes, they've made a show of pulling out politically no they have militarily pulled out so that politically they can stand firm and that brings me to the final sub-question it's because

they are standing from because politically they've not given up their basic enterprise but they don't want the UN in there they don't want their withdrawal verified because of course it can't be if they have the UN in they're in trouble but to cover up for this

they're using all sorts of excuses and pretexts about the UN having been biased over the last 10 years because the Vietnamese have never accepted that their invasion is in violation of the UN Charter and it certainly is, without a doubt the Vietnamese have never accepted that their invasion is in any sense in international law illegal

and of course it's illegal but the Vietnamese talk about proletarian internationalism they talk just like the American government used to incidentally about being invited in by by an indigenous revolutionary force because they pretend that the Heng Sam Rin Hun Sen Party

arose out of an indigenous civil war with the pop-up forces they ignore that they brought all these people out of vietnam and out of vietnamese prisons in fact and put them they claim that there was an indigenous uprising which they were asked to support and in the name of pro-italian internationalism they supported it and their argument is that the people have spoken

they've spoken out against paul pott they supported this indigenous uprising and therefore government and party are genuine governments because they are people's democracies because there's a genuine people's revolutionary party there
This is the significance of the names that were given to the People's Republic of Kampuchea and to the Kampuchean People's Revolutionary Party of Aung San Suu Kyi.
So they won't let the UN come in to verify because the UN hasn't recognized

the so-called legal government from their point of view and now at the Paris conference or in speeches Nguyen Quoc Tac, the Vietnamese foreign minister denounces the UN all the time because it is prejudiced and biased and claims the UN will not be an objective and fair
observer of either a ceasefire or the Vietnamese withdrawal or any other form of international control and supervision.
That's a pretext.
And there's a serious debate here about the legality of everything.
Question three.
What effect will the recent semi-recognition given by the UK and others have on negotiations?
I like the way you put this, semi-recognition.
It was in the paper again today that it did not recognize and had not changed the policy.
I think semi-recognition is too strong here and I think the British position might be a little different from everybody else's so let me as a British academic speak to the British situation first
There have been some particular problems in Britain in the last six or eight months.
Problems within the Foreign Office linked to cabinet instability in Britain itself.
and some problems linked to relations with Vietnam cabinet instability I can deal with very quickly the Thatcher regime's regime the Thatcher government I should call it it is a sort of regime
Thatcher is in a certain amount of political difficulty at the moment.
Economic policy isn't working out too well.
She's isolated in Europe and the opinion polls show that she's not as super popular as she used to be.
In fact, she's a little bit like Reagan.
Her popularity ratings are usually, her personal popularity ratings have usually been a little bit better than the support ratings for her policies.

but in any case the problems internally have led to a couple of major cabinet reshuffles and the foreign ministry has suffered as I point out in this little discussion paper Britain has had three foreign ministers in the last four months and in the British system this represents a certain amount of disorganization

Geoffrey Howe had been foreign minister for a long time and very familiar with Cambodian affairs very sharp on the Cambodian matters but he was sacked for all intents and purposes in July during the cabinet reshuffle and replaced by John Major from the treasury John Major is a specialist on economic matters and doesn't have much experience in foreign affairs
Nevertheless, he was an able person, but you just can't put somebody in that job and expect them to be on top of things overnight.
And then John Major was moved out of the Foreign Office into the Chancellor of the Exchequer's job when Nigel Lawson abruptly resigned from that important job in October.

So British foreign policy has had no strong hand at the helm for many months and this coincides with a real crisis in Hong Kong involving the Vietnamese boat people Britain has agreed, has promised China, that is the PRC that all of the Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong will be out by 1997

and there are now over 50,000 of these people and they're living in appalling conditions really they're incarcerated they're living in prison conditions which they shouldn't have to endure but space problems in Hong Kong are just generally horrific and in fact a lot of these people apparently do not qualify for refugee status in accordance to international law
even though they are afraid to go back to Vietnam and don't have a very good life there.
In any case, for reasons that you and I will probably never fully know about, the British government decided some months ago, this happened before I left Britain,

they decided effectively really in June that they were going to forcibly deport these people from Hong Kong and there then arose a problem with how to get the Vietnamese government to accept them to get the Vietnamese to help Britain out of its dilemma in Hong Kong and its treaty commitments to China so there have been quiet negotiations with Vietnam
And the Vietnamese cause have been looking for some quid pro quo.
And Cambodia always comes up in these discussions.
And Britain, without breaking ranks with the European community and the US, has always said that they will provide aid and will resume trade with Vietnam as soon as they're out of Cambodia.

the Vietnamese say well we're pulling on our troops at the end of September that's the time isn't it so in a sense the Vietnamese have been pushing Britain and maybe Britain before the other European countries for some positive reciprocal response to the withdrawal and in some measure I see
the British government making this small gesture in response to Vietnamese military withdrawals but Britain is not going to recognize the Phnom Penh government and I'm sure they told Vietnam not

Britain is prepared to extend some recognition to Vietnam for having withdrawn militarily, is prepared to extend some recognition to the Hun Sen administration, acknowledging in some measure that it must be part of some settlement, it's not going to be permanently kept in the cold and isolated in Western strategic thinking.

and so the sending of a British diplomat to Phnom Penh to talk with British aid agencies in Phnom Penh but not to anybody in that administration is a halfway gesture it is in no sense recognition and in fact the way the British have done it is to reconfirm that Britain, along with most of the countries of the world

still does not recognize the legality of that government imposed by a foreign invasion and comprised of people who were handpicked by a foreign government and a foreign party For the rest of the countries alluded to here by reference to others I don't know really what to say because nobody else is
gone very far.

the US press has given Hun Sen some really quite extraordinary recognition lately but the US government hasn't budged a bit on the recognition question and I wouldn't expect them to frankly the US is strongly behind the UN position on the question of recognition
France has never recognized either the CGDK or the Phnom Penh government.
France has tried to play a neutral role
tried to play a mediating role as a former colonial power, and it continues to do so today.
This was one of the reasons the Paris Conference was held in Paris rather than elsewhere.
And as far as I'm aware, the French have not budged from their strictly neutral position.
They have a CGDK diplomatic mission in Paris.
They allow
diplomatic missions to come from Phnom Penh.
They have lines to both sides, if you like.
They've always had their aid agencies in Phnom Penh.
Madame Mitterrand has a private aid agency, which has always worked in Phnom Penh.
French policy hasn't changed at all in recent months.
What about the Australian?

the Australian, there's been a lot of noise about the Australian policy and the ambassador here in Bangkok is clearly more sympathetic towards Phnom Penh than some people in the Australian foreign ministry and his position is really not always in keeping with the position of the Australian government and he has recently been rebuked for some of his statements here in Bangkok

Australia's policy is absolutely clear their policy about recognising states and recognising governments is slightly unusual within world legal terms they do not recognise governments, they recognise states so they recognise that there is an independent state of Cambodia

but legal conditions are such that Australia does not officially know I'm putting quotation marks around know where the government of this state of Cambodia is so they do not recognize Phnom Penh they do not recognize the CGDK and officially they have told the Hun Sen government that they will not treat with Phnom Penh in the normal

international diplomatic matter they cannot trade with phnom penh they cannot receive phnom penh delegations as legally recognized delegations in australia and they similarly similarly they cannot do this with cgdk and they will not do it for either government

until the legal position of one or the other is normalized and then Australia will recognize and Australia will trade I've recently received a paper from the Australian Foreign Ministry in which it is clearly stated that Australia will not resume bilateral aid to Cambodia a state it recognizes

until there is an internationally recognized political authority there and they're speaking in terms of an interim political authority as soon as there is some beginning of a series of steps toward the settlement and an interim political authority is established under the auspices of the Paris conference Australia is prepared to resume aid everyone will resume aid then Australia has also repeatedly made it clear

that while it's interested in trade with Indochina and normalizing relations with all of Indochina that its relations with the ASEAN countries and its trade with the ASEAN countries is infinitely more important and Australia has repeatedly said it will not take the lead on Cambodia and on the Himalaya

work with the ASEAN countries and cooperate with the ASEAN countries and will not enter into any relationship with either Vietnam or Cambodia, which will jeopardize its relationships with the ASEAN countries?
Well, I don't think even more needs to be said about that question.
